Succession 1: Grandnephew and adopted son of Julius Caesar
Succession 2: Gradually acquired further power through grants from, and constitutional settlements with, the Roman Senate
Life details 1: Born as Gaius Octavius
Life details 2: First elected Roman consul on 19 August 43 BC

Succession 1: Stepson, former son-in-law and adopted son of Augustus
Life details 1: Died probably of natural causes, allegedly murdered at the instigation of Caligula

Succession 1: Grandnephew and adopted heir of Tiberius, great-grandson of Augustus
Life details 1: Murdered in a conspiracy involving the Praetorian Guard and senators

Succession 1: Uncle of Caligula, grandnephew of Augustus, proclaimed emperor by the Praetorian Guard and accepted by the Senate
Life details 1: Began the Roman conquest of Britain
Life details 2: Probably poisoned by his wife Agrippina, in favor of her son Nero

Succession 1: Grandnephew, stepson, son-in-law and adopted son of Claudius, great-great-grandson of Augustus
Life details 1: Committed suicide after being deserted by the Praetorian Guard and sentenced to death by the Senate

Succession 1: Governor of Hispania Tarraconensis, revolted against Nero and seized power after his suicide, with support of the Senate and Praetorian Guard
Life details 1: Murdered by soldiers of the Praetorian Guard in a coup led by Otho

Succession 1: Seized power through a coup against Galba
Life details 1: Committed suicide after losing the Battle of Bedriacum to Vitellius

Succession 1: Governor of Germania Inferior, proclaimed emperor by the Rhine legions on 2 January in opposition to Galba and Otho, later recognized by the Senate
Life details 1: Murdered by Vespasian's troops

Succession 1: Proclaimed by the eastern legions on 1 July 69 in opposition to Vitellius, later recognized by the Senate
Life details 1: Began construction of the Colosseum

Succession 1: Son of Vespasian
Life details 1: Died of natural causes

Succession 1: Brother of Titus and son of Vespasian
Life details 1: Assassinated in a conspiracy of court officials, possibly involving Nerva

Succession 1: Proclaimed emperor by the Senate after the murder of Domitian
Life details 1: First of the "Five Good Emperors"

Succession 1: Adopted son of Nerva
Life details 1: First non-Italian emperor
Life details 2: His reign marked the geographical peak of the empire

Succession 1: Cousin of Trajan, allegedly adopted on his deathbed
Life details 1: Ended Roman expansionism
Life details 2: Destroyed Judea after a massive revolt

Succession 1: Adopted son of Hadrian
Life details 1: Died of natural causes

Succession 1: Son-in-law and adopted son of Antoninus Pius
Succession 2: Until 169 reigned jointly with his adoptive brother, Lucius Verus, the first time multiple emperors shared power
Succession 3: Since 177 reigned jointly with his son Commodus
Life details 1: Last of the "Five Good Emperors"
Life details 2: Also one of the most representative Stoic philosophers

Succession 1: Adopted son of Antoninus Pius, joint emperor with his adoptive brother, Marcus Aurelius
Life details 1: Died of natural causes

Full Name: Marcus Aurelius Antoninus / Lucius Aelius Aurelius Commodus
Succession 1: Son of Marcus Aurelius
Succession 2: Proclaimed co-emperor in 177, at age 16, becoming the first emperor to be elevated during predecessor's lifetime
Life details 1: Strangled to death in a conspiracy involving his praetorian prefect, Laetus, and mistress, Marcia

Succession 1: City prefect of Rome at Commodus's death, set up as emperor by the praetorian prefect, Laetus, with consent of the Senate
Life details 1: Murdered by mutinous soldiers of the Praetorian Guard

Succession 1: Won auction held by the Praetorian Guard for the position of emperor
Life details 1: Killed on order of the Senate, at the behest of Septimius Severus

Succession 1: Governor of Upper Pannonia, acclaimed emperor by the Pannonian legions following the murder of Pertinax
Life details 1: First non-European emperor

Succession 1: Son of Septimius Severus, proclaimed co-emperor on 28 January 198, at age 10
Succession 2: Succeeded jointly with his brother, Geta, in 211
Life details 1: First child emperor
Life details 2: Granted Roman citizenship to all free inhabitants of the empire
Life details 3: Murdered by a soldier at the instigation of Macrinus

Succession 1: Son of Septimius Severus, proclaimed co-emperor in October 209, succeeded jointly with his older brother, Caracalla
Life details 1: Murdered on order of his brother, Caracalla

Succession 1: Praetorian prefect of Caracalla, accepted as emperor by the army and Senate after having arranged his predecessor's death in fear of his own life
Life details 1: First  non-senator to become emperor, and first emperor not to visit Rome after acceding
Life details 2: Executed during a revolt of the troops in favor of Elagabalus

Succession 1: Son of Macrinus, named co-emperor by his father after the eruption of a rebellion in favor of Elagabalus
Life details 1: Caught in flight and executed in favor of Elagabalus

Succession 1: Cousin and alleged illegitimate son of Caracalla, acclaimed as emperor by rebellious legions in opposition to Macrinus at the instigation of his grandmother, Julia Maesa
Life details 1: Murdered by the Praetorian Guard alongside his mother, probably at the instigation of Julia Maesa

Succession 1: Cousin and adopted heir of Elagabalus
Life details 1: Lynched by mutinous troops, alongside his mother

Succession 1: Proclaimed emperor by Germanic legions after the murder of Severus Alexander
Life details 1: First commoner to become emperor
Life details 2: Murdered by his men during the siege of Aquileia

Succession 1: Proclaimed emperor alongside his son, Gordian II, while serving as governor of Africa, in a revolt against Maximinus, and recognized by the Senate
Life details 1: Oldest emperor at the time of his elevation
Life details 2: Committed suicide upon hearing of the death of his son

Succession 1: Proclaimed emperor alongside his father Gordian I, during revolt in Africa against Maximinus
Life details 1: The shortest-reigning emperor on record
Life details 2: Killed outside Carthage in battle against an army loyal to Maximinus I

Succession 1: Proclaimed emperor jointly with Balbinus by the Senate after death of Gordian I and II, in opposition to Maximinus
Life details 1: Tortured and murdered by the Praetorian Guard

Succession 1: Proclaimed emperor jointly with Pupienus by the Senate after death of Gordian I and II, in opposition to Maximinus
Life details 1: Tortured and murdered by the Praetorian Guard

Succession 1: Grandson of Gordian I, appointed as heir by Pupienus and Balbinus, upon whose deaths he succeeded as emperor
Life details 1: Died during campaign against Persia, possibly in a murder plot instigated by Philip I

Succession 1: Praetorian prefect under Gordian III, seized power after his death
Life details 1: Killed at the Battle of Verona, against Decius

Succession 1: Son of Philip I, appointed co-emperor
Life details 1: Murdered by the Praetorian Guard

Succession 1: Proclaimed emperor by the troops in Moesia, then defeated and killed Philip I in battle
Life details 1: Killed at the Battle of Abrittus, against the Goths

Succession 1: Son of Decius, appointed co-emperor
Life details 1: Killed at the Battle of Abrittus alongside his father

Succession 1: Senator and general, proclaimed emperor after the deaths of Decius and Herennius Etruscus
Life details 1: Murdered by his own troops in favor of Aemilian

Succession 1: Younger son of Decius, named caesar by his father and proclaimed co-emperor by Trebonianus Gallus
Life details 1: Died of plague or murdered by Trebonianus Gallus

Full Name: Gaius Vibius Afinius Gallus Veldumnianus Volusianus
Succession 1: Son of Gallus, appointed co-emperor
Life details 1: Murdered by the soldiers, alongside his father

Succession 1: Commander in Moesia, proclaimed emperor by his soldiers after defeating barbarians, in opposition to Gallus
Life details 1: Murdered by his own troops in favor of Valerian

Succession 1: Obscure figure known only from coinage, may have briefly ruled in Rome between Aemilianus and Valerian
Life details 1: Nothing known

Succession 1: Army commander in Raetia and Noricum, proclaimed emperor by the legions in opposition to Aemilian
Life details 1: Captured at Edessa by the Persian king Shapur I, died in captivity possibly forced to swallow molten gold

Succession 1: Son of Valerian, appointed joint emperor
Succession 2: Sole emperor after Valerian's capture in 260
Life details 1: Faced multiple revolts & barbarian invasions
Life details 2: Murdered in a conspiracy of army officers, involving Claudius II and Aurelian

Succession 1: Son of Gallienus, proclaimed caesar by his father and proclaimed emperor by the praetorian prefect Silvanus while besieged by Postumus
Life details 1: Murdered by troops loyal to Postumus

Succession 1: Army commander in Illyria, proclaimed emperor after Gallienus's death
Life details 1: Died of plague

Succession 1: Brother of Claudius II, proclaimed emperor after his death
Life details 1: Committed suicide or killed at the behest of Aurelian

Succession 1: Commander of the Roman cavalry, proclaimed emperor by Danube legions after Claudius II's death, in opposition to Quintillus
Life details 1: Reunified the Roman Empire

Succession 1: Alleged princeps senatus, proclaimed emperor by the Senate or, more likely, by his soldiers in Campania after Aurelian's death
Life details 1: Died of illness or possibly murdered

Succession 1: Brother or, more likely, half-brother of Tacitus
Life details 1: Murdered by his own troops in favor of Probus

Succession 1: General
Succession 2: Proclaimed emperor by the eastern legions, in opposition to Florianus
Life details 1: Murdered by his own troops in favor of Carus

Succession 1: Praetorian prefect under Probus, seized power before or after Probus's murder
Life details 1: Died in Persia, either of illness, assassination, or by being hit by lightning

Succession 1: Son of Carus, appointed joint emperor shortly before his death
Life details 1: Probably died in battle against Diocletian, likely betrayed by his own soldiers

Succession 1: Son of Carus, succeeded jointly with Carinus
Life details 1: Died while marching to Europe, probably of disease, possibly assassinated

Succession 1: Commander of the imperial bodyguard, acclaimed by the army after death of Numerian, and proceeded to defeat Numerian's brother, Carinus, in battle
Life details 1: Began the last great persecution of Christianity
Life details 3: Died in unclear circumstances, possibly suicide

Succession 1: Elevated by Diocletian, ruled the western provinces
Life details 1: Abdicated with Diocletian, later trying to regain power with, and then from, Maxentius, before being probably killed on orders of Constantine I

Succession 1: Elevated to caesar in 293 by Diocletian, succeeded as eastern augustus upon Diocletian's abdication
Life details 1: Died of natural causes

Succession 1: Maximian's relation by marriage, elevated to caesar in 293 by Diocletian, succeeded as western augustus upon Maximian's abdication
Life details 1: Died of natural causes

Succession 1: Elevated to caesar in 305 by Maximian, promoted to western augustus by Galerius upon Constantius I's death
Life details 1: Surrendered to Maximian and Maxentius, later murdered or forced to commit suicide

Succession 1: Son of Maximian and son-in-law of Galerius, seized power in Italy with support of the Praetorian Guard and his father after being passed over in the succession
Succession 2: Not recognized by the other emperors
Life details 1: Died at the Battle of the Milvian Bridge, against Constantine I

Succession 1: Elevated by Galerius to replace Severus, in opposition to Maxentius
Succession 2: Defeated Maximinus Daza in a civil war to become sole emperor of the East in 313
Life details 1: Defeated, deposed and put to death by Constantine I

Succession 1: Nephew of Galerius, elevated to caesar by Diocletian in 305, and acclaimed as augustus by his troops in 310
Life details 1: Defeated in civil war against Licinius, died shortly afterwards

Succession 1: Frontier commander in Dacia, elevated by Licinius in opposition to Constantine I
Life details 1: Executed in the lead-up to a peace settlement between Licinius and Constantine

Succession 1: A senior bureaucrat, elevated by Licinius in opposition to Constantine I
Life details 1: Deposed by Constantine and banished to Cappadocia, later executed

Succession 1: Son of Constantius I, acclaimed by his father's troops as augustus
Succession 2: Accepted as caesar by Galerius in 306, promoted to augustus in 307 by Maximian, refused demotion to caesar in 309
Life details 1: First Christian emperor and founder of Constantinople
Life details 2: Sole ruler of the Empire after defeating Maxentius in 312 and Licinius in 324

Succession 1: Son of Constantine I
Life details 1: Ruled the praetorian prefecture of Gaul
Life details 2: Killed in an ambush during a war against his brother, Constans I

Succession 1: Son of Constantine I
Life details 1: Ruled Italy, Illyricum and Africa initially, then the western empire after Constantine II's death

Succession 1: Son of Constantine I
Life details 1: Ruled the east initially, then the whole empire after the death of Magnentius
Life details 2: Died of a fever shortly after starting a war againts Julian

Succession 1: Proclaimed emperor by the troops, in opposition to Constans I
Life details 1: Committed suicide after losing the Battle of Mons Seleucus

Succession 1: Son of Eutropia, a daughter of Constantius I
Succession 2: Proclaimed emperor in Rome in opposition to Magnentius
Life details 1: Captured and executed by supporters of Magnentius

Succession 1: General of Constans in Illyricum, acclaimed by the Illyrian legions at the expense of Magnentius
Life details 1: Abdicated in Constantius II's favor, retired, and died 6 years later

Succession 1: Cousin and heir of Constantius II, acclaimed by the Gallic army around February 360
Life details 1: Last non-Christian emperor
Life details 2: Mortally wounded during a campaign against Persia

Succession 1: Commander of imperial household guard
Succession 2: Acclaimed by the army after Julian's death
Life details 1: Possibly died of inhaling toxic fumes or indigestion

Succession 1: General
Succession 2: Proclaimed emperor by the army after Jovian's death
Life details 1: Last emperor to cross the Rhine into Germania
Life details 2: Died of a stroke while yelling at envoys

Succession 1: Brother of Valentinian I, made eastern emperor by his brother (Valentinian retaining the west)
Life details 1: Killed at the Battle of Adrianople

Succession 1: Maternal cousin and intended heir of Julian
Succession 2: Revolted against Valens and captured Constantinople, where the people proclaimed him emperor
Life details 1: Deposed, captured and executed by Valens

Succession 1: Son of Valentinian I
Succession 2: Proclaimed western co-emperor on 24 August 367, at age 8
Succession 3: Emperor in his own right after Valentinian's death
Life details 1: Killed by Andragathius, an officer of Magnus Maximus

Succession 1: General, related to Theodosius I
Succession 2: Proclaimed emperor by the troops in Britain
Succession 3: Briefly recognized by Theodosius I and Valentinian II
Life details 1: Defeated by Theodosius I at the Battle of Save, executed after surrendering

Succession 1: Son of Valentinian I, proclaimed co-emperor on 22 November 375, at age 4
Succession 2: Sole western ruler after the defeat of Magnus Maximus in 388
Life details 1: Dominated by regents and co-emperors his entire reign
Life details 2: Probably suicide, possibly killed by Arbogast

Succession 1: Teacher of Latin grammar and rhetoric, secretary of Valentinian II
Life details 1: Defeated by Theodosius I at the Battle of the Frigidus and executed

Succession 1: Retired general
Succession 3: Ruler of the entire empire after Valentinian II's death
Life details 1: Last emperor to briefly rule over the two halves of the Empire after the Battle of the Frigidus

Succession 1: Son of Theodosius I
Life details 1: Died of natural causes

Succession 1: Son of Theodosius I
Life details 1: Reigned under several successive regencies

Succession 1: Common soldier, proclaimed emperor by the troops in Britain
Life details 1: Surrendered to Constantius, a general of Honorius, and abdicated
Life details 2: Sent to Italy but murdered on the way

Succession 1: Son of Arcadius
Life details 1: Died of a fall from his horse

Succession 1: A leading member of the Senate, proclaimed emperor by Alaric after the Sack of Rome
Life details 1: Deposed by Alaric after reconciling with Honorius
Life details 2: Tried to claim the throne again 414-415  but was defeated and forced into exile

Succession 1: Prominent general under Honorius and husband of Galla Placidia, a daughter of Theodosius I
Life details 1: De facto ruler since 411
Life details 2: Helped Honorius defeat numerous usurpers & foreign enemies

Succession 1: Senior civil servant, seized power in Rome and the west after Theodosius II delayed in nominating a successor of Honorius
Life details 1: Captured by the forces of Theodosius II, brought to Constantinople and executed

Succession 1: Son of Constantius III, grandson of Theodosius I and great-grandson of Valentinian I, installed as emperor of the west by Theodosius II
Life details 1: Faced the invasion of the Huns
Life details 2: Murdered by Optelas and Thraustelas, retainers of Aetius

Succession 1: Soldier and official, proclaimed emperor after marrying Pulcheria, a daughter of Arcadius
Life details 1: Died after a prolonged period of illness

Succession 1: General and civil official, murdered Valentinian III and married his widow, Licinia Eudoxia
Life details 1: Killed by a mob while fleeing during the Vandalic sack of Rome

Succession 1: General
Succession 2: Proclaimed emperor by the Visigoths and Gallo-Romans after the death of Petronius Maximus
Life details 1: Defeated and deposed by the magister militum Ricimer, became a bishop
Life details 2: Died shortly after of either natural causes, strangulation, or being starved to death

Succession 1: General
Succession 2: Proclaimed by the army, backed by Ricimer
Life details 1: Reconquered Gaul, Hispania and Dalmatia

Succession 1: Proclaimed emperor by Ricimer
Life details 1: Died of natural causes

Succession 1: General
Succession 2: Husband of Marcia Euphemia, a daughter of Marcian
Succession 3: Proclaimed western emperor by Leo I
Life details 1: The last effective emperor of the West
Life details 2: Murdered by Gundobad after a civil war with Ricimer

Succession 1: Husband of Placidia, a daughter of Valentinian III
Life details 1: Died of dropsy

Succession 1: General
Life details 1: Deposed by Julius Nepos and made a bishop, subsequent fate unknown

Succession 1: General
Succession 2: Married to a relative of Verina, the wife of the eastern emperor Leo I
Succession 3: Installed as western emperor by Leo
Life details 1: Fled to Dalmatia in the face of an attack by his magister militum Orestes
Life details 2: Continued to claim to be emperor in exile

Succession 1: Proclaimed emperor by his father, the magister militum Orestes
Life details 1: The last western emperor
Life details 2: Deposed by the Germanic general Odoacer and retired
Life details 3: Possibly alive as late as 507 or 511
